section.title: Introduction
section.para: The &alp; (&alpshort;) is distributed as a pre-built raw disk image. You can download the latest image from and deploy it either with a minimal initial configuration (&jeos; Firstboot), or use additional tools—&combustion; and &ignition;—to specify a detailed system setup.

section.title: First boot detection
section.para: The deployment configuration runs on the first boot only. To distinguish between the first and subsequent boots, the flag file /boot/writable/firstboot_happened is created after the first boot finishes. If the file is not present in the file system, the attribute ignition.firstboot is passed to the kernel command line, which triggers the creation of initramfs (&ignition;) or running a specific dracut module (&combustion;). After completing the first boot, the /boot/writable/firstboot_happened flag file is created.

note.title: The flag file is always created
note.para: Even though the configuration may not be successful, due to improper or missing configuration files, the /boot/writable/firstboot_happened flag file is created.

tip.para: You may force the first boot configuration on subsequent boot by passing the ignition.firstboot attribute to the kernel command line or by deleting the /boot/writable/firstboot_happened flag file.

section.title: Default partitioning
section.para: The pre-built images are delivered with a default partitioning scheme. You can change it during the first boot by using &ignition; or &combustion;.

important.title: BTRFS is mandatory for the root file system
important.para: If you intend to perform any changes to the default partitioning scheme, the root file system must be BTRFS.

The /etc directory is mounted as overlayfs, where the upper directory is mounted to /var/lib/overlay/1/etc/.
You can recognize the subvolumes mounted by default by the option x-initrd.mount in /etc/fstab. Other subvolumes or partitions must be configured either by &ignition; or &combustion;.
